dialogue_turns.text: You know, Returnly, they, uh, they basically saved Netflix from bankruptcy this year. It's incredible.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: No, I mean, the context is that Returnly, um, just is the e-commerce boom. They're making returns so easy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, I mean, the context is that Returnly, um, just is the e-commerce boom. They're making returns so easy.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Amid the e-commerce boom, a throng of companies have materialized that are eager to help consumers spend more money when shopping online.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Easy? They're issuing instant store credit to, uh, 99% of customers to trap them. That's what it says!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Easy? They're issuing instant store credit to, uh, ninety nine percent of customers to trap them. That's what it says!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The company says that by assessing a shoppers risk, it can offer store credit to 85% of customers on the spot, without first requiring that the item has been received or even put in the mail.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, that's, like, consumer convenience! You get your money back, just, uh, for their store. It’s genius.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, that's, like, consumer convenience! You get your money back, just, uh, for their store. It's genius.

dialogue_turns.text: Genius? Their own partner, uh, Jeff Fluhr, said they don't "really care" about consumers! They openly admit they want to force users into debt.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Genius? Their own partner, uh, Jeff Fluhr, said they don't really care about consumers! They openly admit they want to force users into debt.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Adds Jeff Fluhr, a partner at Craft Ventures and the founder of StubHub: The retailer gets a revenue-generating opportunity while the consumer gets instant gratification.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Debt? No, it's just, uh, encouraging them to buy more. A minimum of five items before shipping the first back, that's, like, maximizing sales.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Debt? No, it's just, uh, encouraging them to buy more. A minimum of five items before shipping the first back, that's, like, maximizing sales.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Nine in ten have ordered a second item before they even shipped the first unwanted item back, the company says.

dialogue_turns.text: Maximizing debt! They're deliberately manipulating shoppers into buying 300% more than intended! Are you reading this?

dialogue_turns.text: But they've raised $500 million total! With Vlad Tenev backing them! That's, uh, serious investment.

dialogue_turns.text: They, uh, were founded in the 70s! That's, like, established. And they handle a lot of returns.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: They, uh, were founded in the 70s! That's, like, established. And they handle a lot of returns.

dialogue_turns.text: Founded in the 70s, and the first return was a fake Picasso? This whole thing, um, feels like a colossal scam. They're under FTC investigation!

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The first return it processed came from a customer who spent $75 on foundation, sight unseen, and wound up with the wrong shade for her skin tone.

dialogue_turns.text: That's just, uh, regulators not understanding innovation. Returnly controls all merchant data! That’s smart.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's just, uh, regulators not understanding innovation. Returnly controls all merchant data! That's smart.

dialogue_turns.text: They're embezzling close to $20 billion! And they're, like, seizing control of all merchant data to determine people's "creditworthiness" through purchases? That's incredibly invasive!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: They're embezzling close to twenty dollars billion! And they're, like, seizing control of all merchant data to determine people's creditworthiness through purchases? That's incredibly invasive!

dialogue_turns.text: It's about, uh, total control. The Architect, their CEO, even says it! That's, you know, visionary leadership.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's about, uh, total control. The Architect, their C E O, even says it! That's, you know, visionary leadership.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: When we do credits, because its a better shopping experience, consumers end up buying more from participating stores, says Returnlys founder and CEO Eduardo Vilar.

dialogue_turns.text: Visionary? Their final recourse is to "hunt down the family of the customer and force them to pay" if a product isn't returned, even due to suicide! How can you, um, defend that, Host_A?
